A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.

For a group $G$ and a subset $X \subset G$, the subgroup $H$ generated by $X$ is defined as the intersection of all subgroups of $G$ containing $X$. It is the unique smallest subgroup of $G$ containing $X$ and consists of all elements of the form $x_{1}^{\varepsilon_{1}} \cdot \ldots \cdot x_{n}^{\varepsilon_{n}}$ where $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in X$ and $\varepsilon_{1}, \ldots, $\varepsilon_{n} \in \{1,-1\}$, with $n$ varying over $\mathbb{N}$.
A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a monomorphism if it is injective.

An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
A purely inseparable extension is a field extension where the minimal polynomial of any element in the extension has a single root, which is repeated according to the degree of the polynomial.
A field extension $K \subset L$ is called simple if there exists an element $\alpha \in L$ such that $L=K(\alpha)$. The degree $[K(\alpha): K]$ is referred to as the degree of $\alpha$ over $K$.
A field homomorphism \\(\sigma: L \longrightarrow L'\\) between two field extensions \\(L / K\\) and \\(L' / K\\) is called a \\(K\\)-homomorphism if it restricts to the identity map on \\(K\\).
An extension $L / K$ is called separable if it does not contain any inseparable algebraic elements over $K$.
The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.
A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A law of composition is defined as a map from the Cartesian product of a set with itself to the set. Therefore, the concept of a set must be defined to understand the law of composition.
A subgroup generated by a set is defined in the context of a group. Therefore, the concept of a group, which is defined using a law of composition, must be understood first.
A commutative ring is a specific type of ring where the multiplication operation is commutative. The concept of a ring involves a law of composition (addition and multiplication).
A ring monomorphism is a specific type of ring homomorphism, which is defined between two rings. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be understood first.
A factorial ring or unique factorization domain is a specific type of integral domain, which is a type of ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be understood first.

A free system of generators (basis) is defined in the context of an A-module, which is a generalization of the concept of a vector space. The concept of a set is fundamental to understanding modules and vector spaces.
A purely inseparable extension is a type of field extension. Therefore, the concept of a field must be understood first.
A simple field extension is a type of field extension. Therefore, the concept of a field must be understood first.
A K-homomorphism is a field homomorphism between two field extensions. Therefore, the concept of a field must be understood first.
A separable extension is a type of field extension. Therefore, the concept of a field must be understood first.
The symmetric group is defined as the group of all bijective self-maps of a set. Therefore, the concept of a set must be understood first.
